subject: RE: [junit] Some questions about JUnit 4

messageBody:
Jason and Andrew,

Thank you for your perspective that JUnit should include a graphical test
runner. I understand you to be saying that you don't use IDEs, at least not
all the time, and you would like a friendlier presentation of test results
than what is available from the textual test runner.

Our thinking about the role of graphical runners in the base JUnit release
evolved in a couple of steps. First, we noticed that JUnit depended on AWT
and Swing classes even though those classes didn't seem central to the
framework. This is an aesthetic point, but aesthetics often lead us in the
right direction so we trust them. Breaking this dependency required breaking
JUnit into two parts, core and UI. Once we had broken JUnit up we came to
the second step of deciding who should be responsible for the UI. Ant and
the IDEs already have their own user interface and represent the (vast?)
majority of JUnit usage, so there is little value added by maintaining
separate UIs. With our limited time to support JUnit, it didn't make sense
to continue maintaining the graphical runners ourselves.

We aren't against standalone runners in general. One of our goals with JUnit
4 is to make writing runners easier. However, we seldom have code in the
JUnit distribution that we didn't write and there is a widely established
community of JUnit extenders. Because of this we are comfortable letting go
of the graphical runners and encouraging people to write and publish their
own. If there is anything more we can do to aid in this endeavor, please let
us know.

Sincerely yours,

Kent Beck
Three Rivers Institute

> From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On

> Subject: RE: [junit] Some questions about JUnit 4
>
> On Mon, 2005-08-22 at 09:50 +0100, Clarke, Andrew wrote:
> > Was I the only person to be saddened by this announcement?
> Maybe I'm
> > just being sentimental here but the Graphical TestRunner's green
> > bar/red
> > bar was one of the earliest delights of Junit.
> >
> > Besides, as a casual user of Java I have yet to find the energy to
> > learn
> > an IDE. When I do have to code Java I generally use my normal text
> > editor and the graphical test runner, which I find is quicker and
> > easier
> > to use than the text version.
> >
> > I know Kent has an evangelising streak - automated unit testing,
> > xp/agile, etc - which he has used well in the service of
> the software
> > community but I think insisting on the use of an IDE is a
> crusade too
> > far.
>
> I was disappointed by this news as well. I do use an IDE for most of
> the day, but when I have to work remotely I use 'vi' over SSH
> and a GUI
> TestRunner on my local machine. So personally, I would like
> to have at
> least one graphical TestRunner. (Yes, I know that I could set up many
> IDEs to do the same thing -- Eclipse for instance -- but that chews up
> too many resources on my laptop.)
>
> Kent, perhaps you would consider adding a community section to CVS and
> allow us to add code there. You can document this portion of the
> repository as being "unwarranted" (whatever that would mean).
> It would
> allow for the community to add their $0.02. I don't think
> anyone wants
> to make more work for you or Erich, but it would be nice to
> have an easy
> way for everyone to use JUnit in a way that is comfortable to them.
>
> --
> Jason Rogers
